info.title: CrÃ©dit Mutuel Implementation of OAuth2 endpoints for PSD2 TPPs.
info.description:
This specification describes how various OAuth2-related endpoints are
implemented by the CrÃ©dit Mutuel service provider, in the case of TPPs
covered by the PSD2.

The endpoints in this specification are derived from a number of RFCs and
external documents:

  * The OAuth2 framework - [RFC 6749][rfc6749]
  * Proof of Key Code Exchange extension for OAuth2 - [RFC 7636][rfc7636]
  * OAuth 2 Dynamic Client Registration Protocol - [RFC 7591][rfc7591]
  * OAuth 2 Dynamic Client Management Protocol - [RFC 7592][rfc7592]
  * OAuth 2 Token Revocation - [RFC 7009][rfc7009]
  * OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS Client Authentication - [IETF Draft][draft-ietf-oauth-mtls]

The sandbox APIs, for use when qualifying the workflows and APIs,
can be found at `https://oauth2-apisi.e-i.com/sandbox/cm/oauth2`.

The production APIs can be found at `https://oauth2-apisi.e-i.com/cm/oauth2`.

For the OAuth 2 Authorization Code workflow, the following Authorization
URLs are available:
  * `https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/{lang}/sandbox/signin.html` is the URL with which
    TPPs can test the authorization code and SCA workflows for `aisp` and
    `cbpii` scopes in the Sandbox environment;
  * `https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/{lang}/banque/oauth2_authorization.aspx` is the URL
    with which PSUs of CrÃ©dit Mutuel can authorize an AISP or CBPII TPP
    for access to their payment banking accounts;
  * The `{lang}` tag can be replaced by one of the following values:
    ["de","en","es","fr"]

 [rfc6749]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749
 [rfc7009]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7009
 [rfc7591]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591
 [rfc7592]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592
 [rfc7636]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636
 [draft-ietf-oauth-mtls]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-mtls/

tags.name: Token Management
tags.description: Get or revoke access and refresh tokens.

get.summary: The authorization endpoint for the 'authorization_code' workflow.
get.description:
## Specification
This is the [Authorization Endpoint][RFC 6749 Â§3.1], used as part of
the [Authorization Code Grant][RFC 6749 Â§4.1], with the [PKCE
extension][RFC 7636 Â§4.3].

## PSD2 Implementation notes
For PSD2 TPPs, all clients must use the PKCE extension with the
SHA-256 code challenge method.

## Documentation notes
This endpoint is documented here mostly in order to document its
parameters.

The actual URLs of the authorization endpoints are documented on the
[OAuth 2 Endpoints] page on the developer portal.

As a reminder, the following Authorization URLs are available:
  * `https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/{lang}/sandbox/signin.html` is the URL with which
    TPPs can test the authorization code and SCA workflows for `aisp`
    and `CBPII` scopes in the Sandbox environment;
  * `https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/{lang}/banque/oauth2_authorization.aspx` is the
    URL with which PSUs of CrÃ©dit Mutuel can authorize an AISP or CBPII
    TPP for access to their payment banking accounts;
  * The `{lang}` tag can be replaced by one of the following values:
    ["de","en","es","fr"]

 [RFC 6749 Â§3.1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-3.1
 [RFC 6749 Â§4.1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1
 [RFC 7636 Â§4.3]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636#section-4.3
 [OAuth 2 Endpoints]: https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/en/devportal/oauth2-endpoints.html

parameters.name: lang
parameters.description:
The ISO 639-2 code of the language in which the authorization page will be shown to the PSU.
Only the values listed here are supported by CrÃ©dit Mutuel.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The URL suffix of the authorization page. `sandbox/signin.html` is used for the sandbox environment, and `banque/oauth2_authorization.aspx` for the non-sandbox environment.

parameters.name: response_type
parameters.description: The OAuth2 `response_type`. Only the authorization code workflow is supported.

parameters.name: client_id
parameters.description: The OAuth2 `client_id` assigned to the client when it was registered.

parameters.name: redirect_uri
parameters.description: The OAuth2 `redirect_uri`, which must be one of the registered URIs for the client. It is required if the client has registered more than one redirection URI.

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: The OAuth2 `scope` on which the client requires access. It is required because no default scope is positioned.

schema.description:
The different scopes supported for PSD2-related TPPs.

For an authorization_code request, the following values are available:
  * aisp: Account Information
  * aisp extended_transaction_history: Account Information with Extended Transaction History;
  * cbpii: Issuing of card-based payment instruments

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: The OAuth2 `state`, to be retransmitted in the query string when redirecting to the TPP redirection endpoint. We have made this parameter mandatory because its absence implies the presence of a CSRF vulnerability for the TPP.

parameters.name: code_challenge
parameters.description: The OAuth2 PKCE `code_challenge`. Its use is mandatory for PSD2-related clients.

parameters.name: code_challenge_method
parameters.description: The OAuth2 PKCE `code_challenge_method`. Only the S256 method (hashing the `code_verifier` with SHA-256) is supported.

default.description:
A HTML content shown to a user agent to begin the OAuth 2 authorization
process. This endpoint will eventually redirect to the redirection
endpoint specified by the TPP, which will receive the `code` and
`state` parameters as specified by [RFC 6749 Â§4.1.2].

In case parameters are missing or wrong, an error page will be
shown. In case the `client_id` and the `redirect_uri` match, the
user will also be redirected to the redirection endpoint specified
by the TPP, with parameters `error` and `error_description` filled
as specified by [RFC 6749 Â§4.1.2.1].

 [RFC 6749 Â§4.1.2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2
 [RFC 6749 Â§4.1.2.1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1

post.description:
## Specification

The token endpoint, as described in [RFC 6749 Â§3.2], used in three
cases:
 * [Authorization Code Grant][RFC 6749 Â§4.1], with the [PKCE
   extension][RFC 7636 Â§4.5];
 * [Client Credentials Grant][RFC 6749 Â§4.4];
 * [Token Refresh][RFC 6749 Â§6];

## PSD2 Implementation notes

For PSD2 TPPs, all clients are confidential clients, and, in the case
of the "Authorization Code" workflow, must use the PKCE extension with
the SHA-256 code challenge method.

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

### Scopes and token types

This API can deliver two different kinds of tokens:
  1. Tokens that are bound to a bank user PSU. These tokens are
     obtained via the "Authorization Code" workflow, and can be
     refreshed via the use of refresh tokens. These tokens are used
     by AISPs, CBPIIs, and PISPs for accounts and operations on that
     user.
  2. Tokens that are bound only to the TPP, obtained via the "Client
     Credentials" workflow. These tokens are usable only by PISPs for
     access to payment initiation endpoints, and cannot have a scope
     for account or coverage information access.

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [RFC 6749 Â§3.2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-3.2
 [RFC 6749 Â§4.1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1
 [RFC 6749 Â§4.4]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.4
 [RFC 6749 Â§6]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-6
 [RFC 7636 Â§4.5]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636#section-4.3

post.summary: Revoke a refresh token or an access token.
post.description:
## Specification

The revocation endpoint, as described in [RFC 7009 Â§2][1].

 [1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7009#section-2

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495

## Implementation notes

Both access tokens and refresh tokens can be revoked.

 * When an access token is revoked, only that access token becomes invalid; no other tokens are affected.
 * When a refresh token is revoked, all associated access tokens are also revoked.

## Specification
This endpoint follows the specification for OAuth 2 Dynamic Client
Registration, as documented in [RFC 7591 Â§3] and modified by
[RFC 7592 Â§3].

## PSD2 Implementation notes

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

### No registration token

As PSD2 TPPs are authenticated by their client certificate, we have
concluded that implementing the registration access token part of
[Dynamic Client Management (RFC 7592)][RFC 7592] did not bring tangible
security benefits. Therefore, the registration management APIs are
altered in the following way with regard to [RFC 7592]:

  * No registration token is returned when registering a client;
  * No registration token is required to manage a registered client;
  * The management endpoints return a 404 (Not Found) instead of 401
    when the client registration URL does not exist;

### Qualified Sealing Certificates Management
For privacy and security reasons, we have added the requirement that
all Qualified Sealing Certificates that will be used by the PSP must
be registered in the `jwk` metadata value. The API URLs that point to
these keys can then be used in the `keyId` field of the corresponding
HTTP Signature headers.

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [RFC 7591 Â§3]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591#section-3
 [RFC 7592]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592
 [RFC 7592 Â§3]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592#section-3

Location.description: The URL of the created registration.

get.description:
## Specification
This endpoint follows the specification for OAuth 2 Dynamic Client
Management, as documented in [RFC 7592 Â§2.1].

## PSD2 Implementation notes

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

### No registration token

As PSD2 TPPs are authenticated by their client certificate, we have
concluded that implementing the registration access token part of
[Dynamic Client Management (RFC 7592)][RFC 7592] did not bring tangible
security benefits. Therefore, the registration management APIs are
altered in the following way with regard to [RFC 7592]:

  * No registration token is returned when registering a client;
  * No registration token is required to manage a registered client;
  * The management endpoints return a 404 (Not Found) instead of 401
    when the client registration URL does not exist;

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [RFC 7592]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592
 [RFC 7592 Â§2.1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592#section-2.1

put.description:
## Specification
This endpoint follows the specification for OAuth 2 Dynamic Client
Management, as documented in [RFC 7592 Â§2.2].

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

### No registration token

As PSD2 TPPs are authenticated by their client certificate, we have
concluded that implementing the registration access token part of
[Dynamic Client Management (RFC 7592)][RFC 7592] did not bring tangible
security benefits. Therefore, the registration management APIs are
altered in the following way with regard to [RFC 7592]:

  * No registration token is returned when registering a client;
  * No registration token is required to manage a registered client;
  * The management endpoints return a 404 (Not Found) instead of 401
    when the client registration URL does not exist;

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [RFC 7592]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592
 [RFC 7592 Â§2.2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592#section-2.2

delete.description:
## Specification
This endpoint follows the specification for OAuth 2 Dynamic Client
Management, as documented in [RFC 7592 Â§2.3].

## PSD2 Implementation notes

### TPP Authentication

The only supported authentication method for PSD2 clients is the use
of client certificates.

Two kinds of certificates may be used, depending on the circumstances:
  * A Qualified Website Authentication Certificate, as described by
    [ETSI TS 119495]. That kind of certificate can be used
    to access either sandbox or production APIs.
  * A test client certificate provided by CrÃ©dit Mutuel. That kind
    of certificate can be used to access sandbox APIs.

### No registration token

As PSD2 TPPs are authenticated by their client certificate, we have
concluded that implementing the registration access token part of
[Dynamic Client Management (RFC 7592)][RFC 7592] did not bring tangible
security benefits. Therefore, the registration management APIs are
altered in the following way with regard to [RFC 7592]:

  * No registration token is returned when registering a client;
  * No registration token is required to manage a registered client;
  * The management endpoints return a 404 (Not Found) instead of 401
    when the client registration URL does not exist;

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [RFC 7592]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592
 [RFC 7592 Â§2.3]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592#section-2.3

ClientRegistrationId.name: clientRegistrationId
ClientRegistrationId.description: The ID of the client registration.

AcceptHeader.name: Accept
AcceptHeader.description:
A description of a list of content-types that the client would like to receive.
Defined by [RFC 7231, Â§5.3.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-5.3.2)
Depending on the endpoint, the value of this header may be taken in account for content negotiation, or may be ignored.

UserAgentHeader.name: User-Agent
UserAgentHeader.description:
Information about the user agent originating the request.
Documented in [RFC 7231, Â§5.5.3](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-5.5.3)

Forbidden.description: Forbidden. The token is valid, but the operation is not permitted.

ClientIdentification.description: The client ID assigned on registration. Cannot be changed by the client - if the value sent by the client when updating a registration does not match the current value, the request will be rejected.

code.description: The authorization code obtained by the redirection endpoint in the `code` query string parameter.

redirect_uri.description: The `redirect_uri` that was given as a parameter on the authorization endpoint.

code_verifier.description: The `code_verifier` to check the PKCE challenge.

scope.description:
The scope of the requested access token. Can be used to restrict the
new access token to a subset of the scope allowed to the client and
token type.

For a Client Credentials grant, the following scopes are available:
  * pisp: Payment Initiation

refresh_token.description: The `refresh_token` previously provided to the client.

scope.description:
The scope of the requested access token. Can be used to restrict the
new access token to a subset of the scope allowed to the client and
token type.

For a Refresh Token grant, the following scopes are available:
  * aisp: Account Information
  * cbpii: Issuing of card-based payment instruments

token_type.description: The type of the token. Currently only bearer tokens are emitted.

expires_in.description: The lifetime of the access token, in seconds.

refresh_token.description: The refresh token to use, for an 'authorization_code' token request.

scope.description: The effective scope of the newly-obtained token.

error.description: A machine-readable category for the error, as in [RFC 6749, Â§4.1.2.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1).

error_description.description: A human-readable error message that gives details about the error.

error_uri.description: A URL that gives more information about the error.

token_type_hint.description: A hint for the type of token to revoke. If the given token is not found with the given type hint, the search will be extended to other token types.

error.description: A machine-readable category for the error, as in [RFC 6749, Â§4.1.2.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1.2.1).

error_description.description: A human-readable error message that gives details about the error.

error_uri.description: A URL that gives more information about the error.

ClientMetadata.description:
Client-provided metadata.

The metadata values documented here are a subset from the values
described in [RFC 7591 Â§2].

Additional metadata values will be ignored.

### Internationalization
The internationalization mechanism is the one described by [RFC 7591
Â§2.2].

In short, it says that internationalizable keys can be provided in
alternate languages by providing, in the JSON content, a key of the
same name but suffixed with a '#' and an IETF language tag [BCP 47].

Here are our recommendations for providing internationalizable values:
  * A neutral value must be provided if any internationalized version
    is provided;
  * For a given website with a language, script and region, a version
    matching all three will be searched for. Failing that, a version
    matching both language and script will be matched. Failing that,
    the neutral value will be chosen.

 [RFC 7591 Â§2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591#section-2
 [RFC 7591 Â§2.2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591#section-2.2
 [BCP 47]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47

redirect_uris.description: A list of URLs that describes the redirection endpoints for the client. These URLs must be HTTPS URLs. Required if `grant_types` includes the `authorization_code` value.

token_endpoint_auth_method.description:
The method with which to authenticate the token endpoint. For
PSD2-related applications, only one authentication method is defined,
which is the use of mutual-TLS, denoted by value `tls_client_auth`,
as documented in [OAuth 2 Mutual-TLS IETF Draft].

Absolute URI values `urn:fdc:e-i.com:2019:5:oauth:token-endpoint-auth-method:sandbox:psd`
and `urn:fdc:e-i.com:2019:5:oauth:token-endpoint-auth-method:eidas-qwac:psd`,
defined by previous versions of this specification, are deprecated,
and should be replaced by `tls_client_auth`.

Depending on the circumstances, one of two types of certificates will be accepted
for mutual-TLS:

 * On the production environment, only a Qualified Website Authentication
   Certificate (QWAC), with the PSD profile documented in [ETSI TS 119495],
   by a legal entity with the authorization of a NCA to operate as a
   Payment Service Provider, with the roles denoted in the certificate.
   In that case, the metadata value `provider_legal_id` must be set
   to the legal entity ID assigned by the National Competent Authority,
   and, in the case of an agent distinct from the TPP, `client_legal_id`
   must also be set;
 * On the sandbox environment, mutual-TLS can be used with:
   * either a certificate provided by [CrÃ©dit Mutuel][Developer
     Portal];
   * or a Qualified Website Authentication Certificate (QWAC) with
     the PSD profile documented in [ETSI TS 119495];
   In both cases, the certificate must still be valid (neither
   expired nor revoked);

 [ETSI TS 119495]: https://www.etsi.org/standards-search#page=1&search=TS119495
 [Developer Portal]: https://www.creditmutuel.fr/oauth2/en/devportal
 [OAuth 2 Mutual-TLS IETF Draft]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-oauth-mtls/

grant_types.description:
The grant types that can be used on the token endpoint. For PSD2-related use, it is a function of the scopes granted to the client (`authorization_code` and `refresh_token` for AISPs and CBPIIs, `client_credentials` for PISPs).
Other grant types are not supported in a PSD2 context.

response_types.description:
The response types for the redirection endpoint after the `authorization_code` workflow. In a PSD2 context, the implicit workflow is not supported.
This value is required if the `redirect_uris` key is present.

client_name.description:
A human-readable name for the client, that will be shown to the user during the authorization process.
This property is internationalizable.

logo_uri.description:
URI string that specifies a logo for the client, as a data scheme URI. If available, the data will be used to show the user a logo during the authorization process.
The URI must use the data URI scheme, and declare an `image/` MIME type.
This property is internationalizable.

scope.description:
A space-separated list of scope values that the client
has (or requests) access to.

In a PSD2 context, the following values are available:
  * aisp: Account Information
  * extended_transaction_history: Extended Transaction History for AISPs;
  * pisp: Payment Initiation
  * cbpii: Issuing of card-based payment instruments

On the production environment, the requested scope must match the
`rolesOfPSP` field in the PSD2 Qualified Certificate Statement in
the Qualified Certificates in use.

contacts.description:
An array of strings representing ways to contact people responsible for the
client registration.

In this implementation, the strings must be email addresses, and there must
be at least one.

JsonWebKeySet.description:
A JSON Web Key Set object, that describes the public keys and certificates related to the given client.
In the scope of PSD2, the JWK Set must be the set of Qualified Sealing Certificates (QSealC) that can be used by the client to sign requests.

CertificateJsonWebKey.description: A JSON Web Key object that represents a public key certificate. The certificates sent here must be Qualified Sealing Certificates, whose registration matches the Qualified Website Authentication Certificate given for authentication.

kty.description:
The key type. As this will necessarily represent a signing public key, only values `RSA` and `EC` are supported.
It must match the type of the public key of the target certificate (first item in the `x5c` field).

use.description:
The intended usage of the key. If filled, as we intend to register public keys used for signing requests emitted by the client, it must be set to value `sig`.
If not provided, this value will be deduced from the certificate data passed in the `x5c` key.
If provided, it must be coherent with the value in the certificate data.

key_ops.description:
The list of operations for which the key is intended to be used. As the JWKs registered via this API will be used by the ASPSP to verify signatures, the value `verify` must be present in the array.
If not provided, this value will be deduced from the certificate data passed in the `x5c` key.
If provided, it must be coherent with the value in the certificate data.

kid.description:
An ID for the JWK. This ID is automatically generated by the server, and will be stable as long as the client registration is unchanged. It should not be assumed that this ID will be the same if the JWK data is the same.
The `kid` can be used as the value of the `keyId` field of HTTP signatures of requests signed by the certificate referenced by this JWK.

x5c.description:
An array representing the certificate chain that contains the public key.
The first element in the array must be the target certificate, and every following element must be its parent in the chain, up to the root certificate.

items.description: A certificate DER data, encoded as standard base64.

x5u.description:
The URL for the certificate. If set, it can be used in the `keyId` field of HTTP Signatures of requests signed with this key.
As described in the STET API Documentation Framework, this URL must end with an underscore and a fingerprint of the certificate, and it must be a HTTPS URL.
The fingerprint from the URL *must* match the first item sent in the `x5c` field.

ClientRegistration.description:
Client Registration information, as defined by [RFC 7592 Â§3]

This includes both client-provided metadata (potentially altered by the
server) and information set by the server (client ID, registration
access token).

 [RFC 7592 Â§3]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7592#section-3

registration_client_uri.description: The URL on which the client can manage its registration.

error.description: A machine-readable code to categorize the error, as in [RFC 7591, Â§3.2.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7591#section-3.2.2).

error_description.description: A human-readable error message that gives details about the error.

error_uri.description: A URL that gives more information about the error.

error.description: A machine-readable code to categorize the error, as in [RFC 6750, Â§3.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750#section-3.1).

error_description.description: A human-readable error message that gives details about the error.

error_uri.description: A URL that gives more information about the error.
